articles.headline: NBC Will Not Renew ITunes Contract
articles.snippet: NBC Universal and Apple were unable to come to an agreement on pricing, leading to the a withdrawal that highlights escalating tensions between Apple and media companies.
articles.abstract: NBC Universal and Apple were unable to come to an agreement on pricing, leading to the a withdrawal that highlights escalating tensions between Apple and media companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC Universal, unable to come to an agreement with Apple on pricing, has decided not to renew its contract to sell digital downloads of television shows on iTunes.

articles.headline: Dell’s Earnings Rise, but Delays Hinder Recovery
articles.snippet: Dell reported on Thursday that second-quarter earnings rose 46 percent, but production delays are preventing the company from growing as quickly as hoped.
articles.abstract: Dell reported on Thursday that second-quarter earnings rose 46 percent, but production delays are preventing the company from growing as quickly as hoped.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 — Make no mistake, Dell is in the black. But production delays, particularly problems in getting the vivid paint colors of its new line of notebook computers right, are preventing the struggling company from growing as quickly as investors have hoped.

articles.headline: Why a U.S. Subprime Mortgage Crisis Is Felt Around the World
articles.snippet: The global financial turmoil, ignited by the subprime mortgage problems in the U.S., has exposed the downsides of spreading risk so broadly that upheavals are felt worldwide.
articles.abstract: The global financial turmoil, ignited by the subprime mortgage problems in the U.S., has exposed the downsides of spreading risk so broadly that upheavals are felt worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: The evening entertainment for roughly 500 financial executives at the Deutsche Bank global derivatives conference last month in Barcelona did not come cheap — the Rolling Stones reportedly were paid more than $5 million.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Bush Offers Relief for Some on Home Loans
articles.snippet: President Bush announced several steps to help Americans who have credit problems meet the rising cost of their housing loans.
articles.abstract: President Bush announced several steps to help Americans who have credit problems meet the rising cost of their housing loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 — President Bush, in his first response to families hit by the subprime mortgage crisis, announced several steps today to help Americans who have credit problems meet the rising cost of their housing loans.

articles.headline: Shiite’s Tale: How Gulf With Sunnis Widened
articles.snippet: For Shatha al-Musawi, a Shiite member of Parliament in Iraq, the urge to reconcile is being blacked out by distrust.
articles.abstract: For Shatha al-Musawi, a Shiite member of Parliament in Iraq, the urge to reconcile is being blacked out by distrust.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Aug. 30 — Shatha al-Musawi, a Shiite member of Parliament, first encountered the Sunni-Shiite divide on the day the Americans captured Saddam Hussein. Hearing the news with a close Sunni friend named Sahira, Ms. Musawi erupted like a child.

articles.headline: New Worries for Small Banks
articles.snippet: Smaller banks find problems in some commercial real estate loans.
articles.abstract: Smaller banks find problems in some commercial real estate loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: For America’s small banks, the changing financial landscape of the last decade meant that many opportunities were no longer available. The big national banks went after consumer lending and came to dominate the market for credit cards. Lending to big companies had long since migrated away from local banks.

articles.headline: Building a Modern Arsenal in India
articles.snippet: India has a growing military appetite that is attracting American contractors seeking big arms deals.
articles.abstract: India has a growing military appetite that is attracting American contractors seeking big arms deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Aug. 30 — India is developing a military appetite to match its growing economic power.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Cancer Society Focuses Its Ads on the Uninsured
articles.snippet: The American Cancer Society plans to devote its 2007 ad budget to the consequences of inadequate health coverage.
articles.abstract: The American Cancer Society plans to devote its 2007 ad budget to the consequences of inadequate health coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Aug. 30 — In a stark departure from past practice, the American Cancer Society plans to devote its entire $15 million advertising budget this year not to smoking cessation or colorectal screening but to the consequences of inadequate health coverage.
